content: The Act is titled the "National Collegiate and Amateur Athletic Protection Act of 2001". It establishes a Task Force on Illegal Wagering on Amateur and Collegiate Sporting Events. The Attorney General will establish a task force to enforce laws against illegal wagering on amateur and collegiate sporting events. The task force will coordinate enforcement efforts, report violations to Congress, and receive funding of $4,000,000 in 2002 and $6,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2006. Additionally, increased penalties for illegal sports gambling will be implemented. The legislation aims to increase penalties for illegal sports gambling by amending various sections of the United States Code. This includes extending the maximum term of imprisonment to 10 years for offenses related to interstate transmission of bets, transportation of wagering paraphernalia, and illegal gambling businesses involving sporting events. The legislation increases penalties for illegal sports gambling by amending the United States Code. The maximum term of imprisonment for offenses related to interstate transmission of bets, transportation of wagering paraphernalia, and illegal gambling businesses involving sporting events is extended to 10 years. The Director of the National Institute of Justice will conduct a study on minors' involvement in illegal sports gambling. A report will be submitted within 2 years, outlining the extent of minors' participation and recommending actions to prevent it. Additionally, a study on gambling on college and university campuses will be conducted. The Attorney General will establish a panel to study illegal college sports gambling, including the scope, prevalence, organized crime involvement, and enforcement efforts. College Programs to Reduce Illegal Gambling on College Campuses: The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to comply with section 484(s), implementing a comprehensive program to reduce illegal gambling and gambling control disorders. The Higher Education Act of 1965 requires institutions to implement a program to reduce illegal gambling and gambling disorders among students and employees. Institutions must annually report their progress to the Secretary of Education, including statistics on illegal gambling, including online gambling. Recipients of athletically related student aid will lose eligibility if engaged in illegal gambling activities, including sports bribery. Institutions of higher education providing athletically related student aid must report annually to the Attorney General and Secretary of Education on actions taken to address illegal gambling. Amateur sports organizations receiving federal assistance must also report annually on their implementation of measures to combat illegal gambling. SEC. 7. SENSE OF CONGRESS. Illegal sports gambling poses a significant threat to youth, and educational programs should be provided to help them recognize the dangers. Public service announcements should be included in tournament coverage, and sports governing bodies should adopt codes of conduct to prevent illegal gambling among youth. The National Collegiate Athletic Association should collaborate with universities in the United States to conduct scientific research on youth sports gambling and related issues.
